quoteFirst: A portion of the Melville Range lies within three miles of the shore there; and one of its most remarkable hills was named after my esteemed friend, William Jackson Hooker, LL.D., Regius Professor of Botany in the University of Glasgow; and another after Colonel Colby, of the Royal Engineers, one of the Members of the Board of Longitude.
quoteTime: About four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: we came to a stream flowing from a lake, and as it was an excellent boat harbour, we entered it and encamped. It was named Roscoe, after the eloquent historian of the Medici; and a conical hill of the Melville Range, visible from its mouth, received the name of the venerable geographer Major Rennel.
title: Narrative of a Second Expedition to the Shores of the Polar Sea, in the Years 1825, 1826, and 1827
author: Franklin, John, 1786-1847; Richardson, John, Sir, 1787-1865

quoteFirst: A publican might with the same reason charge me three livres a pound for whiting, and if questioned about the imposition, reply, that if I had asked for fish I should have had the same whiting for the fifth part of the money: but that he made a wide difference between selling it as fish, and selling it as whiting. Our felucca came round from Porto Mauritio in the night, and embarking next morning, we arrived at Nice
title: Travels through France and Italy
author: Smollett, T. (Tobias), 1721-1771; Seccombe, Thomas, 1866-1923 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon

quoteFirst: Descending the eastern slopes of the ridge the British carried a second strong position, then attacked a fresh line--chiefly in Rayon Wood--in which were large shelters of reinforced concrete, each capable of holding a company. At
quoteLast: Oosttaverne Village, lying west of the centre of the position, fell. At sun-down the day's objectives had been completely attained, and the advance at certain points exceeded two miles in depth.
title: Ypres and the Battles of Ypres

quoteFirst: "About one week ago I happened to be detailed as a Head-Quarter guard, and
quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
quoteLast: was pacing up and down the beat in front of the General's Head-Quarters. It was a pleasant sun-shiny spring day,--when gadflies like to try their wings, and the ground seems to smoke in all directions,--and the General sat back composedly in the corner of his tent on a camp stool, with his elbow on his knee and his head hanging rather heavily upon his hand.

quoteLast: , though more or less desultory firing continued until dark.  Considering the severity of the engagement on McCook's front, and the reverses that had befallen him, I question if, from that part of the line, much could have been done toward retrieving the blunders of the day, but it did seem to me that, had the commander of the army been able to be present on the field, he could have taken advantage of Bragg's final repulse, and there would have remained in our hands more than the barren field.
title: Personal Memoirs of P. H. Sheridan, Volume 1, Part 2
author: Sheridan, Philip Henry, 1831-1888

quoteLast: we were relieved by the rear line who drove the rebels on past the Whitehouse, into the timber beyond, and there kept up a heavy skirmish firing half the night. Meantime we prepared a sumptuous repast of bacon and hard-tack--coffee was barred--some of the boys lighted fires, but quickly the order came “Fires out!” and they were encouraged to prompt obedience by the dropping shot, which were attracted by the light, gleaming through occasional rifts in the cloud.
title:
Reminiscences of the Chattanooga campaign

quoteTime: about four o'clock in the afternoon
